awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Role of endogenous carbon monoxide (CO) in hypoxia tolerant species
awd_abstract_narration:
Often, carbon monoxide (CO) is thought of as a strictly toxic gas, but CO is also naturally produced in the body from the breakdown of heme, a key component of the primary oxygen-carrying protein (hemoglobin) found in red blood cells. Members of the research team recently discovered that certain species of deep-diving seals have moderately high concentrations of CO in their blood (similar to those measured in heavy cigarette smokers). Currently, these are the only species known to naturally produce such high levels of CO, which may elicit strong protective effects on tissues that experience low oxygen or reduced blood flow, as regularly occurs during diving. This project tests the hypothesis that deep-diving seals produce higher concentrations of CO as a potential adaptive mechanism to avoid injuries associated with their extreme diving behaviors. It will investigate the source of the high CO levels in the blood, how the production of CO is regulated, and the range of CO concentrations in blood and tissues from several species of air-breathing divers. Species shown to produce high concentrations of CO will be further examined to evaluate the potential protective properties associated with the gas. The research has potential applications that could assist in minimizing human reperfusion injuries (e.g., as a result of a stroke). The project is highly collaborative and includes three Early-Career Investigators, two female scientists, one post-doctoral researcher, and several graduate and undergraduate students. Several public education and outreach activities are planned, including contributions to public education at Ano Nuevo State Reserve in California.

The impact of endogenously produced gas molecules on the regulation of physiological processes is a rapidly expanding area of biological research. However, the interactions between these molecules and their biological targets, and the adaptive roles they play in wildlife, are currently unknown. This project investigates the genetic and physiological mechanisms driving CO production and the potential for the gas to elicit cytoprotective effects during hypoxia and/or ischemia in diving mammals. The project tests the hypothesis that higher CO concentrations result from elevated heme-protein stores and a high turnover rate of these stores via short erythrocyte lifespans. It will also test whether CO has beneficial effects in diving species, including cytoprotection, increased hemoglobin-oxygen affinity, and altered mitochondrial function. The results from this study will advance understanding of physiological adaptations for hypoxia tolerance (e.g., in diving, high-altitude, or burrowing species). This collaborative project supports three Early-Career Investigators and promotes research training and education for one post-doctoral researcher, four graduate students, and over 20 undergraduates across six institutions. Results from this study will be incorporated into courses taught by the investigators. Broader Impacts of the project include participation of underrepresented minority groups, enhanced infrastructure for research and education at six institutions, and broad dissemination of research and educational materials to enhance public understanding of key scientific concepts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Carbon monoxide (CO) is produced from the incomplete combustion of carbon-based fuels and is known as 'The Silent Killer'. This is due to the colorless and odorless properties of the gas, and ability of CO to outcompete oxygen for binding sites on heme proteins in the body (e.g., hemoglobin). The gas is also naturally produced during red blood cell turnover and moderate concentrations have shown to regulate cellular pathways involved in protection of tissues from damage caused by fluctuations in blood flow and oxygen. To date, deep-diving northern elephant seals are one of the only animals known to maintain high levels of CO in blood (Tift et al., 2014; Tift and Ponganis, 2019). It is unknown how CO production is regulated in this species or how the gas impacts their physiology. They routinely deplete blood oxygen stores to levels that would damage organs in other mammals, and blood flow to many tissues is drastically reduced while diving and then restored at the surface, which would also lead to injuries in other mammals (e.g., stroke). It is possible that maintenance of higher levels of CO could offer protection to their tissues (Tift et al., 2020).

Here, we examined factors regulating CO production in marine mammals and studied the potential for the gas to offer cytoprotective effects in certain tissues and cells. We performed the first red blood cell lifespan measurements in marine mammals to understand how turnover rates impact CO production (Pearson et al., 2024). Species with higher CO concentrations in blood, tissues, and exhaled breath had longer red blood cell lifespans, higher mass-specific heme stores, and were generally larger and deeper divers. Longer duration breath holds in the larger, deeper-diving species will likely reduce the amount of CO removed from the body through the lungs, resulting in the accumulation of CO in tissues and blood over time. We found that concentrations of CO in blood, skeletal muscle, and exhaled breath increase with age in elephant seals, in concert with expression of genes encoding enzymes involved in CO synthesis and antioxidant defenses (Piotrowski et al., 2021). Our study is the first to measure extravascular tissue CO concentrations in any wild animal, and to report expression of genes associated with endogenous CO production and signaling in blood and muscle of a deep-diving mammal across lifespan. To understand how CO concentrations vary between tissue types, we examined the amount of CO in nine different tissues from stranded bottlenose dolphins. The CO concentration was highest in the liver, skeletal muscle, and spleen, but all tissues had significantly more CO than reported in tissues from smaller rodents, suggesting that maintenance of higher CO concentrations is important for diving mammals that routinely experience hypoxia. We have also been working with elephant seal and human arterial endothelial cells to investigate;  a) differences in the heme oxygenase/carbon monoxide pathway activity under baseline conditions between human and elephant seal endothelial cells, b) effects of hypoxia on the heme oxygenase/carbon monoxide pathway activity in human and elephant seal endothelial cells, and c) effects of inflammation on the heme oxygenase/carbon monoxide pathway activity in human and elephant seal endothelial cells. This work is ongoing and will highlight the importance of this pathway at the cellular level in a diving mammal.

We also investigated the impact of hypoxia and hibernation on CO production in two species of mole rats and thirteen-lined ground squirrels, respectively. Specifically, we studied naked mole rats and Damaraland mole rats to understand the impact of acute and chronic hypoxia on the heme oxygenase/carbon monoxide pathway activity in several different tissues. Like the bottlenose dolphin, we discovered that baseline CO concentration in tissues of the mole rats were much higher than those reported in mice and rats. Hypoxia severity and duration did not result in large variations in tissue CO content or CO production rates, suggesting that these fossorial rodents defend slightly higher CO concentrations in tissues during normoxia and hypoxia when compared to other rodents. This could be due to the cytoprotective effects of the gas at moderate concentrations, or due to the important role of CO as a signaling molecule. Experiments with thirteen-lined ground squirrels allowed us to study the impact of torpor duration and season on the heme oxygenase/carbon monoxide pathway in several different tissues. We found that blood CO is drastically lower while the animals are in torpor, with concentrations increasing 3-5x during brief interbout euthermia events between bouts of torpor and during the summer months. This strongly suggests that higher body temperatures increase the rate of CO production, which is then suppressed during torpor when CO concentrations drop.

Finally, we have collaborated with several different research groups developing CO-releasing pharmaceuticals. These collaborations have highlighted the potent cytoprotective effect of CO in several disease models and have resulted in several publications.
